channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Engineered natural killer cells show their power against blood cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00164-y

A variation on CAR T-cell therapy damps down the number of cancerous cells in people with certain types of lymphoma or leukaemia.
item.dc:title: Engineered natural killer cells show their power against blood cancer

item.title: Audio long read: Long COVID is a double curse in low-income nations — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00224-3

A dearth of research means the condition is often ignored by physicians.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Long COVID is a double curse in low-income nations — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: ‘Sci-fi instrument’ will hunt for giant gravitational waves in space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00254-x

An experiment has been given the go ahead to send lasers to orbit the Sun to hunt for gigantic ripples in space-time.
item.dc:title: ‘Sci-fi instrument’ will hunt for giant gravitational waves in space
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Obesity drugs have another superpower: taming inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00118-4

The blockbuster medications that reduce body weight also reduce inflammation in organs such as the brain, raising hopes that they can treat Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases.
item.dc:title: Obesity drugs have another superpower: taming inflammation
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: ‘People in poverty lack money. So let’s just give them money’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00208-3

Catherine Thomas’s research explores different approaches to alleviating poverty, including cash transfers.
item.dc:title: ‘People in poverty lack money. So let’s just give them money’
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: First aircraft to fly on Mars dies — but leaves a legacy of science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00248-9

The record-setting Mars helicopter Ingenuity broke during a final, fatal flight.
item.dc:title: First aircraft to fly on Mars dies — but leaves a legacy of science
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Publisher Correction: Polθ is phosphorylated by PLK1 to repair double-strand breaks in mitosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07025-8

Publisher Correction: Polθ is phosphorylated by PLK1 to repair double-strand breaks in mitosis
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Polθ is phosphorylated by PLK1 to repair double-strand breaks in mitosis

Author Correction: Reconstitution of Rab- and SNARE-dependent membrane fusion by synthetic endosomes

item.title: This fast-living marsupial chooses sex over sleep — and dies young
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00177-7

Male antechinus make the most of their single breeding season by forgoing shut-eye.
item.dc:title: This fast-living marsupial chooses sex over sleep — and dies young
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: How I learnt to write research papers as a non-native English speaker
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00218-1

Leaving blanks, studying others and paying careful attention to figures all helped Sri Lankan chemist Nuwan Bandara to hone his skills.
item.dc:title: How I learnt to write research papers as a non-native English speaker
item.dc:creator: Nuwan Bandara

item.title: Daily briefing: Meet the data sleuth who spurred the Dana-Farber retractions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00251-0

‘There’s a pretty simple way to prevent all of this,’ he says. Plus, troubled times at Fermilab and when whales walked the Earth.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Meet the data sleuth who spurred the Dana-Farber retractions
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Black hole observations solve cosmic-ray mystery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00223-4

Data from an African observatory show that jets from a collapsed star are capable of producing some of the Galaxy’s fastest particles.
item.dc:title: Black hole observations solve cosmic-ray mystery
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: CRISPR-edited crops break new ground in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00176-8

Scientists in the global south use the popular technique to protect local crops against local threats.
item.dc:title: CRISPR-edited crops break new ground in Africa
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Tracking down tuberculosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00087-8

Improvements in screening and diagnosis could help to eradicate this curable disease.
item.dc:title: Tracking down tuberculosis
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Canada’s oil sands spew massive amounts of unmonitored polluting gases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00203-8

Innovative aircraft-based technique records carbon emissions not tracked before from the industrial region.
item.dc:title: Canada’s oil sands spew massive amounts of unmonitored polluting gases
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Replying to: Probing supernovae and kicks in post-supernova binaries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06848-1

Replying to: Probing supernovae and kicks in post-supernova binaries
item.dc:title: Replying to: Probing supernovae and kicks in post-supernova binaries
item.dc:creator: Noel D. Richardson
Jan J. Eldridge

Probing supernovae and kicks in post-supernova binaries

item.title: A mysterious mountain range lacks roots but still stands tall
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00180-y

Scientists puzzled over the height of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta range in Colombia find that its supporting crust dripped away over time.
item.dc:title: A mysterious mountain range lacks roots but still stands tall

item.title: Gripped by dinosaurs, and a unified theory of behaviour: Books in Brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00204-7

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Gripped by dinosaurs, and a unified theory of behaviour: Books in Brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: A dedicated hypothalamic oxytocin circuit controls aversive social learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06958-w

In mice, the neural mechanisms underlying aversive social learning, specifically avoidance and fear after defeat, involve oxytocin signalling in the anterior subdivision of the ventromedial hypothalamus, ventrolateral part.
item.dc:title: A dedicated hypothalamic oxytocin circuit controls aversive social learning
item.dc:creator: Takuya Osakada

item.title: Coordination of cohesin and DNA replication observed with purified proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07003-6

We study the interplay between cohesin and replication by reconstituting a functional replisome using purified proteins, showing how cohesin initially responds to replication and providing a molecular model for the establishment of sister chromatid cohesion.
item.dc:title: Coordination of cohesin and DNA replication observed with purified proteins
item.dc:creator: Yasuto Murayama
Shizuko Endo
Yumiko Kurokawa
Ayako Kurita
Sanae Iwasaki
Hiroyuki Araki

item.title: Redefining the treponemal history through pre-Columbian genomes from Brazil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06965-x

Reconstruction of four Treponema pallidum genomes associated with human remains from around 2,000 years ago suggests that T. pallidum existed in the Americas and diverged to its modern subspecies before the fifteenth century European contact with the Americas.
item.dc:title: Redefining the treponemal history through pre-Columbian genomes from Brazil
item.dc:creator: Kerttu Majander
Marta Pla-Díaz
Louis du Plessis

Jose Filippini
Luis Pezo-Lanfranco
Sabine Eggers
Fernando González-Candelas
Verena J. Schuenemann

item.title: Green steel from red mud through climate-neutral hydrogen plasma reduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06901-z

Red mud is shown to yield green steel through fossil-free hydrogen-plasma-based reduction, a simple and fast method involving rapid liquid-state reduction, chemical partitioning, and density-driven and viscosity-driven separation.
item.dc:title: Green steel from red mud through climate-neutral hydrogen plasma reduction
item.dc:creator: Matic Jovičević-Klug
Isnaldi R. Souza Filho
Hauke Springer
Christian Adam
Dierk Raabe

item.title: Motion of VAPB molecules reveals ER–mitochondria contact site subdomains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06956-y

High-speed molecular tracking is integrated with three-dimensional electron microscopy to map the diffusion distribution and ultrastructure of endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria contact sites, revealing the ability of high-speed single-molecule imaging to map contact site interface structures and corresponding diffusion landscapes.
item.dc:title: Motion of VAPB molecules reveals ER–mitochondria contact site subdomains
item.dc:creator: Christopher J. Obara
Jonathon Nixon-Abell
Andrew S. Moore
Federica Riccio

item.title: Observing dynamical phases of BCS superconductors in a cavity QED simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06911-x

The dynamical phases of out-of-equilibrium Bardeen–Cooper–Schrieffer superconductors have been simulated using cold atoms levitated inside an optical cavity.
item.dc:title: Observing dynamical phases of BCS superconductors in a cavity QED simulator
item.dc:creator: Dylan J. Young
Anjun Chu
Eric Yilun Song
Diego Barberena

James K. Thompson

item.title: HIV-1 capsids enter the FG phase of nuclear pores like a transport receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06966-w

The HIV-1 capsid behaves like a nuclear transport receptor entering and traversing an FG phase, with its interior serving as a cargo container, bypassing an otherwise effective barrier to viral infection.
item.dc:title: HIV-1 capsids enter the FG phase of nuclear pores like a transport receptor
item.dc:creator: Liran Fu
Erika N. Weiskopf
Onno Akkermans
Nicholas A. Swanson
Shiya Cheng
Thomas U. Schwartz
Dirk Görlich

item.title: The persistence of memory in ionic conduction probed by nonlinear optics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06827-6

Single-cycle terahertz pumps are used to impulsively trigger ionic hopping in battery solid electrolytes, probing ion transport at its fastest limit and demonstrating the connection between activated transport and the thermodynamics of information.
item.dc:title: The persistence of memory in ionic conduction probed by nonlinear optics
item.dc:creator: Andrey D. Poletayev
Matthias C. Hoffmann
James A. Dawson
Samuel W. Teitelbaum
Mariano Trigo
M. Saiful Islam
Aaron M. Lindenberg

item.title: Cortical regulation of helping behaviour towards others in pain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06973-x

A study describes the role of the anterior cingulate cortex in coding and regulating helping behaviour exhibited by mice towards others experiencing pain.
item.dc:title: Cortical regulation of helping behaviour towards others in pain
item.dc:creator: Mingmin Zhang
Ye Emily Wu
Mengping Jiang
Weizhe Hong

item.title: Rapid groundwater decline and some cases of recovery in aquifers globally
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06879-8

Analysis of about 170,000 monitoring wells and 1,693 aquifer systems worldwide shows that extensive and often accelerating groundwater declines are widespread in the twenty-first century, but that groundwater levels are recovering in some cases.
item.dc:title: Rapid groundwater decline and some cases of recovery in aquifers globally
item.dc:creator: Scott Jasechko
Hansjörg Seybold
Debra Perrone
Ying Fan
Mohammad Shamsudduha
Richard G. Taylor
Othman Fallatah
James W. Kirchner

item.title: The HIV capsid mimics karyopherin engagement of FG-nucleoporins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06969-7

Dissection of the nuclear pore complex provides a model in which the HIV capsid enters the nucleus through karyopherin mimicry, a mechanism likely to be conserved across other viruses.
item.dc:title: The HIV capsid mimics karyopherin engagement of FG-nucleoporins
item.dc:creator: C. F. Dickson

D. A. Jacques

item.title: Transcription–replication interactions reveal bacterial genome regulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06974-w

Single-cell expression data from bacteria are used to classify gene regulatory architectures in relation to gene expression dynamics and the cell cycle, revealing distinct categories of gene regulatory mechanisms.
item.dc:title: Transcription–replication interactions reveal bacterial genome regulation
item.dc:creator: Andrew W. Pountain

item.title: Testing quantum electrodynamics in extreme fields using helium-like uranium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06910-y

An experiment sensitive to higher-order quantum electrodynamics effects and electron–electron interactions in the high-Z regime was performed using a multi-reference method based on Doppler-tuned X-ray emission from stored relativistic uranium ions with different charge states.
item.dc:title: Testing quantum electrodynamics in extreme fields using helium-like uranium

item.title: Nozaki–Bekki solitons in semiconductor lasers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06915-7

Free-running stable optical dissipative solitons, called Nozaki–Bekki solitons, are created in a ring semiconductor laser; their spontaneous formation with tuning of laser bias eliminates the need for an external optical pump.
item.dc:title: Nozaki–Bekki solitons in semiconductor lasers

item.title: Toxic red mud could be turned into ‘green’ steel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00213-6

Researchers extract useful metal from industrial waste, and how analysis of blood proteins could help unravel the mystery of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Toxic red mud could be turned into ‘green’ steel
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Daily briefing: Why coffee varieties taste different
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00219-0

The most complete sequencing yet of Coffea arabica’s genome. Plus, how stress triggers gut pain, and a fresh take on Einstein’s achievements.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why coffee varieties taste different
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Leading US particle-physics lab faces uncertain future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00150-4

Several organizations are vying for the contract to manage Fermilab, after it received failing grades from the US Department of Energy.
item.dc:title: Leading US particle-physics lab faces uncertain future
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: Groundwater decline is global but not universal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00070-3

Measurements of groundwater levels in 170,000 wells reveal the global extent of groundwater decline. But the data also show that such depletion is not inevitable in a changing climate, providing hope for a resilient water future.
item.dc:title: Groundwater decline is global but not universal
item.dc:creator: Donald John MacAllister

item.title: Dana-Farber retractions: meet the blogger who spotted problems in dozens of cancer papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00202-9

Nature talks to Sholto David about his process for flagging image manipulation and his tips for scientists under scrutiny.
item.dc:title: Dana-Farber retractions: meet the blogger who spotted problems in dozens of cancer papers
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Unethical studies on Chinese minority groups are being retracted — but not fast enough, critics say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00170-0

Campaigners who want scrutiny of biometrics research on Uyghurs, Tibetans and other groups are frustrated by slow progress.
item.dc:title: Unethical studies on Chinese minority groups are being retracted — but not fast enough, critics say
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Iron extracted from hazardous waste of aluminium production
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00071-2

Millions of tonnes of ‘red mud’, a hazardous waste of aluminium production, are generated annually. A potentially sustainable process for treating this mud shows that it could become a source of iron for making steel.
item.dc:title: Iron extracted from hazardous waste of aluminium production
item.dc:creator: Chenna Rao Borra

item.title: Tyrannomorphs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00156-y

It’s the new normal.
item.dc:title: Tyrannomorphs
item.dc:creator: Graham Robert Scott

item.title: Syphilis microbe’s family has plagued humans for millennia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00191-9

Ancient DNA recovered from Brazilian remains shows that treponemal diseases originated some 10,000 years earlier than previously thought.
item.dc:title: Syphilis microbe’s family has plagued humans for millennia
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00178-6

Wine-fermentation jars used in Georgia today hint at the properties of ancient vintages.
item.dc:title: The clever system that gave Roman wines an amber colour and nutty aroma

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00187-5

Are we part of a unified work of absurd art?
item.dc:title: Are we part of a unified work of absurd art?
item.dc:creator: Ryan Shirlow

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: AlphaFold predicts thousands of possible psychedelics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00206-5

For the first time, predicted protein structures have been shown to be just as useful for drug discovery as experimentally derived ones. Plus, a plant-inspired robot that grows like a vine and how an AI figured out geometry.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: AlphaFold predicts thousands of possible psychedelics
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Can autoimmune diseases be cured? Scientists see hope at last
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00169-7

After decades of frustration and failed attempts, scientists might finally be on the cusp of developing therapies to restore immune ‘tolerance’ in conditions such as diabetes, lupus and multiple sclerosis.
item.dc:title: Can autoimmune diseases be cured? Scientists see hope at last
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: How does chronic stress harm the gut? New clues emerge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00188-4

A bacterium in the intestines of stressed mice interferes with cells that protect against pathogens.
item.dc:title: How does chronic stress harm the gut? New clues emerge
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: How Einstein built on the past to make his breakthroughs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00171-z

The iconic physicist’s theories of relativity and atomic motions were not so revolutionary, a penetrating history argues.
item.dc:title: How Einstein built on the past to make his breakthroughs
item.dc:creator: Helge Kragh

item.title: John L. Heilbron (1934–2023), historian of ‘big science’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00195-5

Rigorous historian who shed light on how researchers’ personalities and institutions are central to the development of scientific knowledge.
item.dc:title: John L. Heilbron (1934–2023), historian of ‘big science’
item.dc:creator: Cathryn Carson

item.title: Cities matter to the world’s future — science must serve them better
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00167-9

From governance to climate impacts, the world’s urban environments face many difficulties. A new journal, Nature Cities, aims to bring together researchers who are rising to the challenge.
item.dc:title: Cities matter to the world’s future — science must serve them better

item.title: Coping with climate change could be a matter of what building you’re in
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03934-2

Extreme heat and cold brought on by climate change put people at risk. Beefing up building codes now could help to save lives.
item.dc:title: Coping with climate change could be a matter of what building you’re in
item.dc:creator: Meredydd Evans

item.title: All arabica coffee is genetically similar: how can beans taste so different?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00165-x

Flavour variations are mainly the result of changes at the chromosome level, sequencing effort finds.
item.dc:title: All arabica coffee is genetically similar: how can beans taste so different?
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Two-faced AI language models learn to hide deception
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00189-3

‘Sleeper agents’ seem benign during testing but behave differently once deployed. And methods to stop them aren’t working.
item.dc:title: Two-faced AI language models learn to hide deception
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Daily briefing: How to disassemble a fusion reactor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00196-4

What we’ll learn from the long process of decommissioning the pioneering JET reactor. Plus, China’s new dark matter lab is the biggest and deepest yet, and the debate over whether megalodon was stocky or slim.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How to disassemble a fusion reactor
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Computers make mistakes and AI will make things worse — the law must recognize that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00168-8

A tragic scandal at the UK Post Office highlights the need for legal change, especially as organizations embrace artificial intelligence to enhance decision-making.
item.dc:title: Computers make mistakes and AI will make things worse — the law must recognize that

Deciphering cell states and genealogies of human hematopoiesis

item.title: How I make stretchy electronics for medicine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00174-w

Mahmoud Tavakoli works on wearable electronic devices that are less invasive than standard equipment.
item.dc:title: How I make stretchy electronics for medicine
item.dc:creator: Patricia Maia Noronha

item.title: China’s new dark-matter lab is biggest and deepest yet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00166-w

The laboratory is scaling up its equipment to hunt for dark matter.
item.dc:title: China’s new dark-matter lab is biggest and deepest yet
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Seven technologies to watch in 2024
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00173-x

Advances in artificial intelligence are at the heart of many of this year’s most exciting areas of technological innovation
item.dc:title: Seven technologies to watch in 2024
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: To curb plastic pollution, industry and academia must unite
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00155-z

Collaboration is key to making plastic use greener as soon as possible. Our experience yields tips on how to set up industry–academic partnerships.
item.dc:title: To curb plastic pollution, industry and academia must unite
item.dc:creator: Collin P. Ward
Christopher M. Reddy
Brian Edwards
Steven T. Perri

item.title: Daily briefing: Japanese spacecraft makes a pin-point landing on the Moon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00193-7

Japan has become the fifth country to land a lunar spacecraft. Plus, Nature’s pick of the technologies to get excited about and how to go further with open science.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Japanese spacecraft makes a pin-point landing on the Moon
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The open-science movement for sharing laboratory materials gains momentum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00172-y

Many researchers support open science, but how can they translate this view into behaviours to boost sharing?
item.dc:title: The open-science movement for sharing laboratory materials gains momentum
item.dc:creator: Andy Tay

item.title: Japan’s successful Moon landing was the most precise ever
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00151-3

Landing within 100 metres of its target zone, the craft has pioneered a new image-based automatic navigation system. But its mission might be cut short.
item.dc:title: Japan’s successful Moon landing was the most precise ever
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: Pioneering nuclear-fusion reactor shuts down: what scientists will learn
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00135-3

The decommissioning of the Joint European Torus near Oxford, UK — a test bed for ITER — will take until 2040 and be studied in detail.
item.dc:title: Pioneering nuclear-fusion reactor shuts down: what scientists will learn
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Publisher Correction: Intermediate conformations of CD4-bound HIV-1 Env heterotrimers

item.title: Flexible geothermal power makes it easier to harness Earth’s inner heat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00127-3

Next-generation plants that respond to demand could be key to making a low-carbon energy source more economically appealing.
item.dc:title: Flexible geothermal power makes it easier to harness Earth’s inner heat

item.title: Science’s fake-paper problem: high-profile effort will tackle paper mills
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00159-9

EXCLUSIVE: Poor-quality studies are polluting the literature — a group will study the businesses that produce them to stem the flow of bogus research.
item.dc:title: Science’s fake-paper problem: high-profile effort will tackle paper mills
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘I never felt I was going to work’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00182-w

Remembering life at Bell Labs’ ‘factory of ideas’ as it moves home. Plus, AlphaFold can find potential new psychedelics and biomarkers predict the risk of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘I never felt I was going to work’
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham
